clues: Home to a green statue gifted by France in the 1800s.
Nicknamed 'The Big Apple' and known for its Broadway theaters.
fun_fact: The Statue of Liberty was originally a copper color before oxidizing to its iconic green patina.
Times Square was once called Longacre Square before being renamed in 1904.
trivia: New York City has 468 subway stations, making it one of the most complex transit systems in the world.
The Empire State Building has its own zip code: 10118.

clues: This city has the busiest pedestrian crossing in the world.
A paradise for anime, manga, and cutting-edge tech lovers.
fun_fact: Tokyo was once a fishing village called Edo before becoming a sprawling metropolis.
Tokyo's train system is so punctual that delays over 5 minutes require official apologies.
trivia: Tokyo has more Michelin-starred restaurants than any other city.
You can find vending machines that sell everything from hot meals to t-shirts.

clues: Known for its romantic ambiance and sparkling iron tower.
Famous for fashion, pastries, and iconic art museums.
fun_fact: The Eiffel Tower was initially considered an eyesore and was nearly dismantled.
There's only one stop sign in all of Paris.
trivia: Paris was originally a Roman city named Lutetia.
It's illegal to name a pig 'Napoleon' in France.

clues: This city lies on two continents.
Famous for the Hagia Sophia and bustling bazaars.
fun_fact: Istanbul was formerly known as Byzantium and Constantinople.
The Grand Bazaar has over 4,000 shops, making it one of the largest markets in the world.
trivia: It's the only city in the world that spans both Europe and Asia.
Istanbul has more mosques than any other city in Turkey.

clues: Known as the 'Paris of South America'.
Birthplace of tango and home to colorful streets like Caminito.
fun_fact: Buenos Aires has over 280 theaters — more than any other city worldwide.
The city's name means 'Fair Winds' in Spanish.
trivia: Eva Perón (Evita) is buried in Buenos Aires' famous Recoleta Cemetery.
It has a bookstore located in a former theater: El Ateneo Grand Splendid.

clues: Famous for colorful houses along Nyhavn and fairy tale vibes.
This city inspired the world of Hans Christian Andersen.
fun_fact: Copenhagen is home to Tivoli Gardens, one of the world's oldest amusement parks.
It's ranked as one of the happiest cities in the world.
trivia: More than half of the population commutes by bicycle daily.
Copenhagen was once a Viking fishing village.

clues: Famous for its sail-shaped opera house overlooking a stunning harbor.
The largest city in Australia with iconic beaches like Bondi.
fun_fact: The Sydney Harbour Bridge is nicknamed 'The Coathanger' due to its arch-based design.
The Sydney Opera House has over one million roof tiles.
trivia: Sydney's New Year's Eve fireworks display is one of the first major celebrations seen globally each year.
The city was founded as a British penal colony in 1788.

clues: Home to a massive statue of Christ with outstretched arms.
Famous for its carnival celebrations and Copacabana Beach.
fun_fact: The name means 'January River' although there is no actual river there.
It was briefly the capital of the Portuguese Empire from 1808 to 1821.
trivia: The Christ the Redeemer statue is struck by lightning several times a year.
Rio has the largest urban forest in the world inside a city.

clues: This city is located near some of the world's most famous ancient triangular structures.
The largest city in Africa, situated along the banks of the Nile River.
fun_fact: Cairo means 'The Victorious' in Arabic.
Khan el-Khalili bazaar has been operating since the 14th century.
trivia: The city is nicknamed 'The City of a Thousand Minarets' due to its numerous mosques.
Greater Cairo is home to over 20 million people, making it one of the most densely populated cities on Earth.

clues: A city built on water with canals instead of streets.
Famous for gondolas, carnival masks, and sinking a little each year.
fun_fact: Venice is built on 118 small islands connected by over 400 bridges.
The city has no roads, just canals and pedestrian pathways.
trivia: Venetian gondoliers must pass a rigorous exam and often inherit their position through family.
The city is sinking at a rate of about 1-2 millimeters per year.

clues: Home to the world's tallest building and man-made islands shaped like a palm tree.
A desert city known for luxury shopping and ultramodern architecture.
fun_fact: Dubai has the world's only 7-star hotel, the Burj Al Arab.
The city transformed from a small fishing village to a global metropolis in just 50 years.
trivia: About 85% of Dubai's population consists of expatriates.
The Dubai Mall is so large it would take over 14,000 Olympic swimming pools to fill it.

clues: An island city-state known for cleanliness and futuristic gardens.
Famous for its strict rules and the iconic Marina Bay Sands hotel.
fun_fact: Singapore is one of only three city-states in the world.
It changed from a third-world country to first-world in a single generation.
trivia: Chewing gum is banned in Singapore to maintain cleanliness.
The national anthem is printed in microtext on the back of the $1000 note.

clues: Famous for its vibrant red buildings and bustling medina.
Known for maze-like souks and the lively Jemaa el-Fnaa square.
fun_fact: Marrakech is known as the 'Red City' due to the color of its buildings and walls.
The city's medina is a UNESCO World Heritage site.
trivia: Marrakech was founded in 1062 and was once the capital of Morocco.
The city inspired fashion designer Yves Saint Laurent, who owned the Majorelle Garden.

clues: Former imperial capital with over 1,600 Buddhist temples.
Famous for geisha districts, traditional gardens, and cherry blossoms.
fun_fact: Kyoto was spared from atomic bombing during WWII due to its cultural significance.
The city served as Japan's capital for over 1,000 years.
trivia: Kyoto has 17 UNESCO World Heritage Sites.
The city follows a strict building code to preserve its traditional appearance.

clues: Known for its medieval Astronomical Clock and castle complex.
Called the 'City of a Hundred Spires' for its Gothic architecture.
fun_fact: Prague Castle is the largest ancient castle complex in the world.
The city's historic center remained largely undamaged during World War II.
trivia: The Dancing House in Prague was inspired by dancers Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers.
The world's first pilsner beer was created in the Czech Republic.

clues: Located near the meeting point of two oceans with a famous flat-topped mountain.
Known for its harbor, biodiversity, and wineries.
fun_fact: Table Mountain has its own cloud formation called the 'tablecloth.'
It's home to the world's highest commercial bungee jump from a bridge.
trivia: Cape Town was the first place in South Africa where Europeans settled.
The city hosts the world's largest individually timed bicycle race.

clues: Famous for its elaborate canal system and narrow houses with gabled facades.
Known for bicycles, tulips, and historic museums.
fun_fact: Amsterdam has more bridges than Venice – over 1,200.
The narrowest house in Amsterdam is only 2.02 meters (6'7") wide.
trivia: Many buildings in Amsterdam are tilted forward intentionally to prevent furniture damage when moving items up the narrow staircases.
There are approximately 881,000 bicycles in Amsterdam – more than its population.

clues: Known for Antoni Gaudí's whimsical architectural masterpieces.
A coastal city famous for Las Ramblas and its Gothic Quarter.
fun_fact: La Sagrada Familia has been under construction since 1882 and won't be finished until 2026.
Barcelona has 9 UNESCO World Heritage Sites, 7 of which were designed by Gaudí.
trivia: Barcelona was home to Pablo Picasso during his formative years.
The city's grid layout was designed by urban planner Ildefons Cerdà in the 19th century.

clues: Built on the ruins of an ancient Aztec city on a lake.
The oldest capital city in the Americas, known for its vibrant culture and cuisine.
fun_fact: Mexico City is sinking at a rate of about 20 centimeters per year.
It was built on the ruins of Tenochtitlan, the ancient Aztec capital.
trivia: It's home to the only royal castle in the Americas: Chapultepec Castle.
Mexico City has the most museums of any city in the world.

clues: The world's northernmost capital city, powered almost entirely by geothermal energy.
Known for its colorful buildings, Viking history, and proximity to stunning natural wonders.
fun_fact: Reykjavik means 'Smoky Bay' in Icelandic, named for the steam rising from hot springs.
In summer, Reykjavik experiences nearly 24 hours of daylight.
trivia: About 60% of Iceland's population lives in Reykjavik.
The city has no trains, trams or metros - just buses and cars.

clues: Home to Bollywood and a colonial-era arch gateway overlooking the Arabian Sea.
India's financial center with extreme wealth alongside large slum areas.
fun_fact: Mumbai was originally seven separate islands that were joined through land reclamation.
The city's dabbawalas deliver over 200,000 lunch boxes daily with near-perfect accuracy.
trivia: Mumbai's film industry, Bollywood, produces more movies annually than Hollywood.
Dharavi, in Mumbai, is one of Asia's largest slums but also a thriving economic center.

clues: Known for classic American cars, colonial architecture, and vibrant music scene.
Capital city with a famous seafront boulevard called the Malecón.
fun_fact: Havana's historic center is a UNESCO World Heritage site.
The city is sometimes called 'The Rome of the Caribbean' due to its historical importance.
trivia: Havana's National Capitol Building was modeled after the U.S. Capitol.
Ernest Hemingway lived near Havana for about 20 years.

clues: Built on swampland by Peter the Great as Russia's 'Window to the West.'
Known for the Hermitage Museum, canals, and White Nights phenomenon.
fun_fact: The city has changed its name three times: St. Petersburg, Petrograd, and Leningrad.
It has 342 bridges spanning its many canals and waterways.
trivia: The Hermitage Museum houses over 3 million items, including the world's largest collection of paintings.
During summer White Nights, the sun barely sets, and the city hosts a famous arts festival.

clues: One of the oldest cities in the world, sacred to three major religions.
Contains the walled Old City divided into four quarters.
fun_fact: Jerusalem has been destroyed and rebuilt at least twice.
The city has been captured and recaptured 44 times throughout history.
trivia: Jerusalem syndrome is a psychological phenomenon where visitors develop religious psychosis.
The Old City walls were built by Suleiman the Magnificent in the 16th century.

clues: Famous for ornate shrines, floating markets, and vibrant street life.
The Thai capital with an ultralong ceremonial name abbreviated as Bangkok.
fun_fact: Bangkok's full ceremonial name is the longest city name in the world with 168 letters.
It was once known as the 'Venice of the East' due to its extensive canal system.
trivia: Bangkok is home to the world's largest Chinatown by area.
The city sinks 2-3 centimeters every year due to excessive groundwater pumping.

clues: Once the capital of the Inca Empire, located high in the Andes.
Gateway city to Machu Picchu with impressive stone architecture.
fun_fact: The city's layout was designed in the shape of a puma, sacred to the Incas.
Cusco means 'navel of the world' in the Quechua language.
trivia: Many buildings in Cusco were built on foundations of Inca stonework that survived earthquakes.
The city sits at an elevation of 3,400 meters (11,200 feet) above sea level.
